recommended.name: Talar tilt test
recommended.procedure: The ankle is held in the neutral position, examiner stabilised the tibia just above the ankle and then tries to force the ankle into maximum inversion. The ROM can be measured or compared with the contralateral side.Inversion laxity suggests injury to calcaneofibular and anterior talofibular ligaments (ATFL).

recommended.name: Anterior Drawer Test
recommended.procedure: Patient sits with knee flexed at 90 deg and ankle in plantarflexion of about 10 deg. The lower leg is stabilised by the examiner and the force patient’s heel forward over the tibia. If positive, the talus can be felt sliding forwards and backwards. Laxity indicates tear of the ATFL.

recommended.name: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)
recommended.procedure: The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.

recommended.name: Cervical Distraction Test
recommended.procedure: The patient lies supine and the neck is positioned comfortably.  The examiner places hand around the patient’s mastoid process. The examiner then slightly flexes the patient’s neck and pull the head towards your torso.Test is positive if the symptoms reduces or is eliminated with traction.

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bicycle Stress Test
recommended.procedure: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

recommended.name: Two-stage Treadmill Test
recommended.procedure: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

recommended.name: The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
recommended.procedure: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.

recommended.name: Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
recommended.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

recommended.name: Modified Schrober’s test
recommended.procedure: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

recommended.name: Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.

recommended.name: Instruct the patient to flex the arm up to 90 deg with the elbow in full extension.Then ask pt to adduct arm 10-15 deg medial to sagittal plane. recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

questions.questionText: Have you had a previous history of a shoulder dislocation?
Did the first episode occur with a pull on an abducted, laterally rotated-extended arm?
Do you experience a catching sensation followed by numbness or weakness (Dead-arm syndrome) when making overhead arm movements?

rule_out: rotator cuff disorder and cervical radiculitis

recommended.name: Apprehension Test
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Patient is in sitting or lying position, the examiner lifts the arn gently into ABduction, external rotation and then extension. Test is positive if Pt senses that humeral head is about to slip out anteriorly and body stiffens in apprehension.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: The test is repeated with the anterior part of shoulder protected.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: Fulcrum’s Test
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Pt lies supine, arm ABducted up to 90 deg. The examiner places their hands over the shoulder to set the fulcrum base. The humeral head is levered forward by extending and externally rotating arm. The patient immediately becomes apprehensive.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: Drawer’s Test
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Patient lies supine , scapula is stabilised with one hand while the upper arm is grasped firmly with the other, and manoeuvring is done forward and backward (like a drawer)
recommended.procedure: . The drawer’s test is positive if instability is marked.

questions.questionText: Do you have a history of generalised Rheumatoid Arthritis?
Do you experience pain and swelling in both shoulder joints?
Do you smoke?
Do you have episodes of fever that resolve spontaneously?
Is swelling present anteriorly and superiorly to the shoulder?
Is swelling present in the axilla?
Do you experience increasing limitations in performing self-care (styling hair, dressing, shaving)?

recommended.name: Radiographic confirmation – check for periarticular erosions, subchondral sclerosis, and resorption.
recommended.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.

questions.questionText: Have you had a previous history of injury, shoulder dislocation, or painful arc syndrome?
Do you feel the pain more at night?
Is your shoulder movement restricted across ALL joint motions?

rule_out: Adhesive Capsulitis. Extension is free in Adhesive Capsulitis

questions.questionText: Do you experience early morning stiffness?
If yes, does the stiffness wane within 30 minutes of waking?

recommended.name: Radiographic confirmation – check for distortion of the joint, subchondral sclerosis, osteophyte formation, and narrowing of articular space.
recommended.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.

questionResponseTests.question: Have you had a past episode of an ankle sprain?

recommended.name: Talar tilt test
recommended.procedure: The ankle is held in the neutral position, examiner stabilised the tibia just above the ankle and then tries to force the ankle into maximum inversion. The ROM can be measured or compared with the contralateral side.Inversion laxity suggests injury to calcaneofibular and anterior talofibular ligaments (ATFL).

recommended.name: Anterior Drawer Test
recommended.procedure: Patient sits with knee flexed at 90 deg and ankle in plantarflexion of about 10 deg. The lower leg is stabilised by the examiner and the force patient’s heel forward over the tibia. If positive, the talus can be felt sliding forwards and backwards. Laxity indicates tear of the ATFL.

recommended.name: Special Test for Recurrent Lateral Instability
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

questionResponseTests.question: Where is your pain worse?

recommended.name: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)
recommended.procedure: The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.

recommended.name: Cervical Distraction Test
recommended.procedure: The patient lies supine and the neck is positioned comfortably.  The examiner places hand around the patient’s mastoid process. The examiner then slightly flexes the patient’s neck and pull the head towards your torso.Test is positive if the symptoms reduces or is eliminated with traction.

recommended.name: Radiographic confirmation
recommended.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if cervical rotation on the affected side is less than 60 degrees.

recommended.name: MRI test
recommended.procedure: MRI imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures and confirm diagnosis.

recommended.name: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)
recommended.procedure: The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.

recommended.name: Cervical Distraction Test
recommended.procedure: The patient lies supine and the neck is positioned comfortably.  The examiner places hand around the patient’s mastoid process. The examiner then slightly flexes the patient’s neck and pull the head towards your torso.Test is positive if the symptoms reduces or is eliminated with traction.

recommended.name: Provocative Tests
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Maudsley’s test
recommended.procedure: Resisted extension of the middle finger elicits pain

recommended.name: Cozen’s test
recommended.procedure: Pain on resisted wrist extension

recommended.name: Mill’s Sign
recommended.procedure: Pt closes hands, dorsiflexes wrist and elbow is extended. The examiner then forces the wrist into palmar flexion against resistance; pain in the epicondyle is positive.

recommended.name: Patient resists wrist flexion with the forearm in extension and supination (i.e. therapist resists wrist extension with the forearm in extension and supination)
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: The test is positive if pain is elicited.
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

questionResponseTests.question: Where is your pain located?

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

questionResponseTests.question: Is the pain you feel aggravated by prolonged walking, standing and lumbar extension?

recommended.name: Bicycle Stress Test
recommended.procedure: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

recommended.name: Two-stage Treadmill Test
recommended.procedure: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

recommended.name: The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
recommended.procedure: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if a wide-based gait is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if Trendenlenburg’s sign is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if Achilles tendon reflex is diminished

recommended.procedure: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

recommended.name: Two-stage Treadmill Test
recommended.procedure: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

recommended.name: The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
recommended.procedure: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if a wide-based gait is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if Trendenlenburg’s sign is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if Achilles tendon reflex is diminished

questionResponseTests.question: Was the pain onset immediately after a heavy lifting?

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

recommended.name: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
recommended.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.

recommended.name: Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (Wasserman sign)
recommended.procedure: Patient is in prone position, knee is flexed and hip is extended. Reproduction of pain in anterior thigh is positive.

recommended.name: Kernig Test
recommended.procedure: Patient’s neck is flexed, hip flexed and the leg is extended. Pain is reproduced in this position.

recommended.name: Milgram Test
recommended.procedure: pain is reproduced on straight leg elevation for 30 seconds.

recommended.name: Radiographic confirmation
recommended.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check for tenderness in the paraspinal musculature

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check for spasms in the paraspinal musculature

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check for decreased reflexes: patellar and ankle jerk

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check for trendenenburg’s sign

recommended.name: MRI test.
recommended.procedure: MRI imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures and confirm diagnosis.

questionResponseTests.question: Do you have a family history of ankylosing spondylitis or any other autoimmune diseases?

entryCriteria.description: Age (common in teens and early adults)

recommended.name: Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
recommended.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

recommended.name: Modified Schrober’s test
recommended.procedure: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

recommended.name: Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Occiput to wall distance- Normally is 0
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Tragus to wall distance- Normally is < 15cm
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Intermalleolar distance- Normally >100 cm
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Confirmatory test through laboratory investigations.
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

recommended.name: Modified Schrober’s test
recommended.procedure: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

recommended.name: Speed Test
recommended.procedure: Place pt’s arm in shoulder flexion, forearm supination and elbow extension. The examiner then applies pressure to the arm as downward action.

recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Yergasom’s test
recommended.procedure: Pt places the forearm in the supine position, and the examiner applies resistance against supination.

recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: Instruct the patient to flex the arm up to 90 deg with the elbow in full extension.Then ask pt to adduct arm 10-15 deg medial to sagittal plane. recommended.name: Apprehension Test
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Patient is in sitting or lying position, the examiner lifts the arn gently into ABduction, external rotation and then extension. Test is positive if Pt senses that humeral head is about to slip out anteriorly and body stiffens in apprehension.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: The test is repeated with the anterior part of shoulder protected.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: Fulcrum’s Test
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Pt lies supine, arm ABducted up to 90 deg. The examiner places their hands over the shoulder to set the fulcrum base. The humeral head is levered forward by extending and externally rotating arm. The patient immediately becomes apprehensive.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: Drawer’s Test
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Patient lies supine , scapula is stabilised with one hand while the upper arm is grasped firmly with the other, and manoeuvring is done forward and backward (like a drawer)
recommended.procedure: . The drawer’s test is positive if instability is marked.

conditionSummary.firstQuestion: Have you had a past episode of an ankle sprain?

recommended.name: Talar tilt test
recommended.procedure: The ankle is held in the neutral position, examiner stabilised the tibia just above the ankle and then tries to force the ankle into maximum inversion. The ROM can be measured or compared with the contralateral side.Inversion laxity suggests injury to calcaneofibular and anterior talofibular ligaments (ATFL).

recommended.name: Anterior Drawer Test
recommended.procedure: Patient sits with knee flexed at 90 deg and ankle in plantarflexion of about 10 deg. The lower leg is stabilised by the examiner and the force patient’s heel forward over the tibia. If positive, the talus can be felt sliding forwards and backwards. Laxity indicates tear of the ATFL.

recommended.name: Special Test for Recurrent Lateral Instability
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check for widening of the medial joint space in the mortise view, check if talus is tilted, check for fracture or dislocation of the proximal fibula.

recommended.name: Squeeze Test
recommended.procedure: Compress the leg firmly above the ankle. Test is positive if pain is felt over the syndesmosis.

conditionSummary.firstQuestion: Where is your pain worse?

recommended.name: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)
recommended.procedure: The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.

recommended.name: Cervical Distraction Test
recommended.procedure: The patient lies supine and the neck is positioned comfortably.  The examiner places hand around the patient’s mastoid process. The examiner then slightly flexes the patient’s neck and pull the head towards your torso.Test is positive if the symptoms reduces or is eliminated with traction.

recommended.name: Maudsley’s test
recommended.procedure: Resisted extension of the middle finger elicits pain

recommended.name: Cozen’s test
recommended.procedure: Pain on resisted wrist extension

recommended.name: Mill’s Sign
recommended.procedure: Pt closes hands, dorsiflexes wrist and elbow is extended. The examiner then forces the wrist into palmar flexion against resistance; pain in the epicondyle is positive.

recommended.name: Patient resists wrist flexion with the forearm in extension and supination (i.e. therapist resists wrist extension with the forearm in extension and supination)
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: The test is positive if pain is elicited.
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.procedure: Palpate for biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa with arms flexed, shoulder ABducted and forearm in supination.

conditionSummary.firstQuestion: Where is your pain located?

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

conditionSummary.firstQuestion: Do you experience paraesthesia or abnormal sensation in the affected leg?

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

recommended.name: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
recommended.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if knee jerk reflex is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if ankle jerk reflex is present

conditionSummary.firstQuestion: Is the pain you feel aggravated by prolonged walking, standing and lumbar extension?

recommended.name: Bicycle Stress Test
recommended.procedure: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

recommended.name: Two-stage Treadmill Test
recommended.procedure: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

recommended.name: The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
recommended.procedure: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if a wide-based gait is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if Trendenlenburg’s sign is present

recommended.name: Clinical Observation
recommended.procedure: Check if Achilles tendon reflex is diminished

conditionSummary.firstQuestion: Was the pain onset immediately after a heavy lifting?

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

recommended.name: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
recommended.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.

recommended.name: Femoral Nerve Stretch Test (Wasserman sign)
recommended.procedure: Patient is in prone position, knee is flexed and hip is extended. Reproduction of pain in anterior thigh is positive.

recommended.name: Kernig Test
recommended.procedure: Patient’s neck is flexed, hip flexed and the leg is extended. Pain is reproduced in this position.

recommended.name: Milgram Test
recommended.procedure: pain is reproduced on straight leg elevation for 30 seconds.

recommended.name: Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
recommended.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

recommended.name: Modified Schrober’s test
recommended.procedure: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

recommended.name: Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Occiput to wall distance- Normally is 0
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Tragus to wall distance- Normally is < 15cm
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Intermalleolar distance- Normally >100 cm
recommended.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

recommended.name: Patient is in sitting or lying position, the examiner lifts the arn gently into ABduction, external rotation and then extension. Test is positive if Pt senses that humeral head is about to slip out anteriorly and body stiffens in apprehension.

recommended.name: Pt lies supine, arm ABducted up to 90 deg. The examiner places their hands over the shoulder to set the fulcrum base. The humeral head is levered forward by extending and externally rotating arm. The patient immediately becomes apprehensive.
recommended.procedure: CT scan to provide detailed cross-sectional imaging.

recommended.name: Patient lies supine , scapula is stabilised with one hand while the upper arm is grasped firmly with the other, and manoeuvring is done forward and backward (like a drawer)
recommended.procedure: . The drawer’s test is positive if instability is marked.

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)
recommended.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.

recommended.name: Bragard Test
recommended.procedure: This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

recommended.name: Lasegue’s Test (Straight-Leg Raise)

recommended.name: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
recommended.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.

recommended.procedure: Check if knee jerk reflex is present

recommended.name: Bicycle Stress Test
recommended.procedure: Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.

recommended.name: Two-stage Treadmill Test
recommended.procedure: The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.

recommended.name: The Lumbar Extension-Loading Test
recommended.procedure: The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.

recommended.name: The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
recommended.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

recommended.name: Modified Schrober’s test
recommended.procedure: Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

recommended.name: Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.
